The essence of the problem is that the information provided by a TSHC solution allows identifying a group of cohorts that crossed node 3 in time step 3 and node 4 in time step 4, but it provides only partial information about the priority relationship between these cohorts before and after this link. So we cannot determine which pairs of cohorts are fully overlapping, partially overlapping, or have strict priority relationship. Table 4B shows a slight modification from Table 4A, where the exit order from node 4 is switched, first cohorts A and D and then cohorts B and C. In this case the CPC interpretation can be p(A,3) = p(A,4) = p(D,3) = p(D,4) = 1 and p(B,3) = p(B,4) = p(C,3) = p(C,4) = 2. This interpretation does satisfy FIFO perfectly, while total flows do not change at all. The existence of two variants in Table 4, both satisfying FIFO definition #8, indicate that without additional assumptions time-step-histories may not be sufficient to fully determine priorities in dynamic models. It may be possible to enhance FIFO definition #8 in a way that excludes the situation illustrated in Table 4. However, more complex examples can be constructed, and ensuring that all such circumstances are handled properly could be fairly cumbersome. Similar complexities should be expected in any solution representation that allows partial overlaps. To begin with, there are several possibilities for partial overlap. For two partially overlapping cohorts c 1, c 2 the edges of the exact crossing intervals can be in one of eight situations: 1 a portion of c 1 is prior to c 2 and a portion of c 2 is after c 1, T − (c 1, n) < T − (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n) < T + (c 2, n) 2 a portion of c 1 is prior to c 2 and they end together, T − (c 1, n) < T − (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n)= T + (c 2, n) 3 a portion of c 1 is prior to c 2 and another portion of c 1 is after c 2, T − (c 1, n) < T − (c 2, n) < T + (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n) 4 c 1 and c 2 start together and a portion of c 2 is after c 1, T − (c 1, n)= T − (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n) < T + (c 2, n) 5 c 1 and c 2 start together and a portion of c 1 is after c 2, T − (c 1, n)= T − (c 2, n) < T + (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n) 6 a portion of c 2 is prior to c 1 and another portion of c 2 is after c 1, T − (c 2, n) < T − (c 1, n) < T + (c 1, n) < T + (c 2, n) 7 a portion of c 2 is prior to c 1 and they end together, T − (c 2, n) < T − (c 1, n) < T + (c 1, n)= T + (c 2, n) 8 a portion of c 2 is prior to c 1 and a portion of c 1 is after c 2, T − (c 2, n) < T − (c 1, n) < T + (c 2, n) < T + (c 1, n) Any transition from one of these eight situations to another constitutes by itself a violation of FIFO (in the sense that a CPC interpretation satisfying FIFO definition #6 is not feasible). This is in addition to the complication illustrated in Table 4. A tentative conclusion from these observations is that the priority functions in the CPC and CB solutions are important for enabling direct and finite FIFO verification. 9 Summary and conclusions The concept of first-in-first-out is very straight forward, and can be easily expressed in a natural (although not necessarily fully formal) manner, for example by FIFO definition #1. Continuous space cumulative-volume profile (CSCP) solutions can be used to formalize the definition of perfect FIFO, as in FIFO definition #2. Many continuous flow dynamic models represent the solution only at nodes, and such discrete-space cumulative-volume profile (DSCP) solutions are just as sufficient for purposes of FIFO verification. This can be done by route-to-route comparison, as in FIFO definition #3, or by route-to-link comparison as in FIFO definition #4. The FIFO verification process can be potentially finite if cohorts are introduced, whether they are associated with continuous crossing times (CCTC) or with complete priorities (CPC), using FIFO definitions #5 and #6 respectively. In addition, cohorts can be grouped into bundles, as in CB solutions. All of the above solution representations and perfect FIFO definitions are in essence equivalent, as proven formally in this paper. Proving FIFO is a direct outcome of the ability to support the CB representation, and possibly the case with CCTC or CPC representations. On the other hand, DSCP and CSCP representations do not offer a direct way for proving FIFO. The last representation considered in this paper is by time-step-history-cohorts (TSHC). Since the number of time-steps is finite, the number of possible histories is also finite. Therefore such solution representation is by definition finite-dimensional. The number of cohorts in such solutions could be fairly large, but may still be practically tractable, at least in some cases. Intuitively it may seem as if time-step-histories should also be sufficient to ensure FIFO, but unfortunately this is not the case. The natural way to define FIFO in association with TSHC solutions, FIFO definition #8, is not equivalent to the other definitions of perfect FIFO discussed here. In addition, by itself this definition is not sufficient to uniquely determine the priority rules, thus enabling multiple solutions to the same situation. Finally, if cohorts with identical time-step-history over their shared segments are assumed to have equal priority, and if such cohorts are expected to proceed spanning the same range of time steps with equal proportions, contradictory requirements may arise under certain circumstances. A key message of this paper is that perfect network-wide FIFO requires unbounded number of discretized elements of flow. It is true that allowing the discretization points to be determined during the solution computation process may be useful not only for satisfying perfect FIFO, but also for example in exact grid-free wave-front methods. In both cases the number of breakpoints/events may grow quickly with the model duration. It should be clarified that this conclusion is not proven formally in the paper, yet the arguments made in the paper are sufficient (in our opinion) to realize why this conclusion is reasonable. As such, this is only a tentative conclusion. In summary, from all of the representations considered in this paper, cohort bundles seem to be the most promising direction. While its structure is a bit cumbersome, and not as intuitive as the other alternatives, it can be used to demonstrate perfect FIFO, and it overcomes (at least partially) the circumstances that lead to infinite verification process with other representations. Further exploration of cohort bundle solutions, especially in terms of tractability, remains a subject for future research. Acknowledgment Insights and comments by Michiel Bliemer, Mark Raadsen and three anonymous reviewers are greatly appreciated. coredata.dc:description: Abstract Dynamic models of traffic require answers for many issues. One of them is the way priorities of different traffic streams (commodities) are managed. This is particularly challenging when flows are treated as continuous. It is common to consider the First-In-First-Out (FIFO) rule as a baseline for setting priorities; but most practical continuous flow dynamic models do not satisfy FIFO perfectly. This paper examines the difficulties associated with full adherence to network-wide FIFO. We examine six different ways to represent dynamic flow solutions over a network, and for each representation we discuss whether it is sufficient for verifying FIFO, whether the verification process is finite, and whether proving FIFO can be directly implied. Throughout the evaluation eight alternative definitions of FIFO are considered, seven of them are shown to be essentially equivalent, while the last definition is not, and may therefore be considered as “weak” FIFO. The most promising representation appears to be the one denoted as “cohort bundles,” while somewhat more abstract than the other representations, supporting this representation directly shows perfect FIFO satisfaction. Further evaluation of this representation remains a subject for future research. In a nutshell, the key conclusion of this analysis is that in order to satisfy perfect network-wide FIFO the number of discretized elements of flow should probably be allowed to grow quickly and unboundedly with model duration, and it cannot be determined a-priori. These insights about the challenges of incorporating FIFO in continuous flow dynamic models, which may be relevant also for other behavior-based priority rules, can help modelers and practitioners set realistic expectations regarding the level of control over priority rules that can be achieved within finite-dimensional continuous flow dynamic models.
coredata.dc:title: Representation requirements for perfect first-in-first-out verification in continuous flow dynamic models
